content:
Diagnosis
	1. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of esophagus
	Date of diagnosis
	January 2024

	Treatment aim
	Palliative

	Summary of completed treatment and relevant dates

	Surgery
	Not indicated

	Radiotherapy
	15 Feb 2024 - Whole brain radiotherapy 20Gy in 5 fractions
	1 Mar 2024 - Palliative radiotherapy to T8 vertebra 8Gy single fraction

	Chemotherapy
	Jan-Mar 2024 - 3 cycles Cisplatin/5-FU/Pembrolizumab

	Clinical studies
	None

	Current disease status
	Progressive disease with clinical deterioration

	Current issues
	1. Progressive dysphagia requiring NG feeding
	2. Worsening bone pain
	3. New onset confusion and ataxia

	Summary of consultation
	This 62-year-old gentleman was reviewed today with his wife and daughter. Unfortunately, he has experienced significant clinical deterioration over the past 2 weeks. His dysphagia has worsened requiring NG feeding, and he is experiencing increased bone pain despite optimal analgesia. Most concerning is the development of new confusion and unsteady gait over the past 72 hours.

Urgent MRI brain performed yesterday shows progression of known cerebral metastases with increasing perilesional edema, despite whole brain radiotherapy completed 6 weeks ago. CT chest/abdomen/pelvis demonstrates progressive disease with enlarging liver metastases and new pulmonary nodules. His performance status has declined from ECOG 2 to 3-4.

After careful discussion with [redacted name] and his family, we have made the decision to discontinue systemic anti-cancer therapy given his marked clinical deterioration and poor performance status. The focus will shift to optimal symptom control.

	Further investigations
	None planned

	Medication prescribed
	1. Dexamethasone 8mg BD
	2. Increased MST to 60mg BD
	3. Continued antiemetics

	Follow up
	1. Urgent referral to palliative care team - completed today
	2. Community palliative care referral - completed today
	3. Next oncology review in 1 week

	Required GP actions
	1. Please monitor neurological status
	2. Support with community palliative care engagement
	3. Consider home visit given reduced mobility
